entry.title: Create a parked invoice(MIR7) based on a purchase order (BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_CREATE).
entry.content:
Hello, 

 

I have a requirement to create a parked invoice based on a PO so i opted to use the BAPI 'BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_PARK'.

My problem is that when i use the table SELECTPO to assign the PO to the invoice it doesn't retrieve the items of the PO like in the screenshot be

I'am sharing the code i used to create a parked invoice using the FM above:

DATA: ls_headerdata TYPE bapi_incinv_create_header.

ls_headerdata-doc_date = '20250812'.
ls_headerdata-pstng_date = '20250812'.
ls_headerdata-doc_type = 'KR'. 
ls_headerdata-currency = 'EUR'.
ls_headerdata-comp_code = '1000'. 
ls_headerdata-ref_doc_no = 'TEST NEW modif'.

ls_headerdata-diff_inv = ls_ekko-lifnr.
ls_headerdata-PMNTTRMS = 'XXXX'. 
ls_headerdata-gross_amount = 1100.
ls_headerdata-invoice_ind = 'X'.
ls_headerdata-calc_tax_ind = 'X'.

* SelectPo
data lt_selectpo type STANDARD TABLE OF BAPI_INCINV_SELECT_PO.
data ls_selectpo type BAPI_INCINV_SELECT_PO.
ls_selectpo-po_number = '4500000xxx'.
ls_selectpo-po_item = '00010'.
append ls_selectpo to lt_selectpo.

CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_PARK'
EXPORTING
headerdata = ls_headerdata
IMPORTING
invoicedocnumber = lv_invoicedocno
fiscalyear = lv_fiscalyear
TABLES
itemdata = lt_itemdata
taxdata = lt_taxdata
selectpo = lt_selectpo
return = lt_return.
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT'
EXPORTING
wait = abap_true.
"--- Check Return Messages
LOOP AT lt_return INTO ls_return.
WRITE: / ls_return-type, ls_return-message.
ENDLOOP.

 

Does anyone have any idea on how to do it ?

 

Thanks In advance

Mohamed

entry.title: Error de timbrado " El valor de SubsidioCausado no debe ser mayor al maximo permitido"
entry.content:
Buen día

En el timbrado del recibo de nomina se presenta un error con el tope maximo permitido de subsidio al empleo.

El periodo de nomina a timbrar tiene un periodo retroactivo del mes anterior.  La suma del subsidio al empleo de cada periodo supera el tope; en este caso supero 475.  Como controlar este tope en periodos de meses diferentes?

Gracias de antemano.

entry.title: RAP: Change key in Entity
entry.content:
Hello,

In a list report I built a custom object page.

The details entities are a join (left outer join because the zeta table is empty at the beginning) between I_PROJECTMILESTONEDATA and a zeta table. The two are linked on the milestone field.

At the press of the save button, the save_modified method is called, the Zeta table is updated with the fields inserted by the user.

On press of the button "Duplicate row", the user can copy a selected row, fill the data and save.

The problem is that the Odata v4 method rise and error because the new row has the same index (milestone) of the copied one.

I think the problem could be resolved  implementing late numbering but I cannot make it work.

Any help is appreciated.

Regards

Filippo

entry.title: Re: Custom Field value is not picked up by SAP21 Customer...
entry.content:
Hello @JastinC1 

When the C_FinInvoiceHeaderFDP form’s item node pulls data from I_OperationalAcctgDocItem, your custom field on business context FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM is not automatically included. To resolve this issue, it is necessary to extend the FDP data source to enable the form to access your YY1 field. The feature 'Maintain Data Source Extensions' is particularly useful in this regard. SAP Help Portal-Accounting Document Item: Operational View

Recommended checklist

In Custom Fields: open your YY1 field → Enable Usage for Form Templates and Data Source Extensions → Publish. SAP Help Portal-Creating Custom Fields in SAP S/4HANA Cloud System

In Maintain Data Source Extensions: pick C_FinInvoiceHeaderFDP → add your YY1 field by navigating the association to the item (I_OperationalAcctgDocItem) node → Publish. SAP Help Portal: Creating Data Source Extensions

In Maintain Form Templates: re-download/update your template, rebind the new field on the item context, upload it, and test in Create Correspondence. SAP Help Portal

Just a quick note: if your YY1 field doesn’t appear in the association browser when extending C_FinInvoiceHeaderFDP, create a tiny Custom CDS View that exposes the YY1 value for the accounting line, then pull it in via the data-source extension path. This is the standard workaround when a field isn’t reachable directly in the FDP’s association graph. SAP Help Portal-Create CDS Views for Debit and Credit Line
GenAI Assisted Content (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition). SAP Help – Custom Fields & Maintain Data Source Extensions; CDS view documents for I_OperationalAcctgDocItem; App Extensibility for Create Correspondence. SAP Help Portal: Creating Data Source Extensions

SAP Learning-Using Custom Fields and Logic

Custom Fields and Logic App F1481

SAP Community blog-Simple extensibility of Data Sources for Output Forms in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: in S/4hana cloud public logistic context, add custom...
entry.content:
Hello @nerevar 

Thank you for your question.

Consider Custom Business Objects, Fields, and Logic to give you some details. However, the Batch object is currently not released for Key User Extensibility in Public Cloud. This means that you cannot add custom fields to the Batch object while using the custom field logic app.

As you mentioned you can use SAP_COM_0337 but this will only support the standard fields.

Alternatively, if you need to extend the data model, the best practice in public cloud is to create a custom business object or you make use of the side-by-side extension on BTP. This allows you to link your custom object to your batch using the reference key and expose it through OData service and integrate it with your MES.

In regard to ABAP SDK, you cannot extend to the batch tables in public cloud. That approach applies on to on-prem or private cloud deployments.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: RAP: Change key in Entity

entry.title: Re: How to Extract Transactional Data into Migration File...
entry.content:
Hello @Sesan 

Thank you for your question.

Consider Migrate Your Data - Migration Cockpit & SAP API Business Hub for details. Please note that the Migration Cockpit only provides upload template for migration objects. There is currently no standard function to automatically export existing transactional data into these sample templates. This is because migration objects are built for inbound loading and not for extraction. However, there are,some best practices you should consider:

  • Using released OData or SOAP APIs to extract your data from your source tenant. Consult S/4HANA Cloud APIs for more details.
  • Accessing released CDS views through custom analytical queries app for your transactional objects. This provides you with the option to filter company code, plant, etc. and export.
  • It is advised to us Data Migration templates. For reconciliation, you will need to export data manually or through APIs. This will enable you transform it into the template format.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud Communication Management Translations
entry.content:
Hello @XinXin 

Thank you for your question.

Consider consulting Manage Translations to give you more insights.

However, in Public Cloud not all custom technical objects are supported for translation through the Manage translation app. In public cloud, the technical objects you want to translate them to is not enabled for key user translation.

  • A work around could be to maintain descriptive texts in a single language and ensure you name them consistently.
  • You also have the possibility to raise an influence request if multi-language support is critical for your project. This can be done on the customer influence portal.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Error when using the new App...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn 

Thank you for your question.

These references Import Master Data - Business Partners (New) & Export Master Data will help provide some details. However, considering the import app expects the original XML format generated by the export app, editing the file in Excel could break the XML structure and potentially cause what you are experiencing. Import Master Data - Business Partners (New)

Even if you are moving between tenants, the process still requires a defined source system to be selected in the app. If you don’t define this, it can also cause it to fail.

One more thing to check is if your file size meets the recommendation. If that is the case, I recommend you split it.

Finally, flickering in the UI seems to be a refresh issue. Consider clearing your browser cache or use a different browser. You can also use GUI for HTML access through the app finder.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom Logic S/4 Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi @Rawel 

Thank you for your question.

You can achieve the desired scenario by using In-App Extensibility in combination with Outbound Communications through the communication scenarios.

Consult the Communication Management link below for more details. https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/2e84a10c430645a88bdbfaaa23ac9ff7.html?locale=en-US

Please note that direct HTTP calls to external endpoints are not supported inside ABAP custom logic in public cloud. Instead best practice is to define your custom comms scenario, register your inhouse endpoint as a comms system and arrangement and then call the released HTTP remote API.

Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for Key User Extensibility

Creating Custom Logic

Communication Arrangements

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to extend validity with SAP ALM user
entry.content: please also refer to 3378674 - SAP Cloud ALM User with status "Expiring in xx Days" Cause A user exists not only in SAP Cloud ALM, but must also exist on the BTP platform (XSUAA) and in the IAS connected to SAP Cloud ALM. If a user is created in SAP Cloud ALM, the user is automatically created on the BTP platform. But if the user is then deleted on the BTP platform, or if the user ID is changed on the platform, the user is no longer in sync. Such users are automatically deactivated in SAP Cloud ALM after a grace period of 30 days. For this period, the user is in status 'expires soon'. Resolution This usually happens either if a user is really offboarded, in this case just wait until the expiration time is over. It can happen if there was a change in the IAS configuration that leads to a change of user ID (e.g. from email to login name). In this case, there will probably be two entries in SAP Cloud ALM User Management for each user, one with the old and one with the new User ID. It should be decided by customer whether the IAS configuration change was correct or not: If no, return to the original IAS configuration. Then the users are reactivated as soon as they login (if this happens within the grace period). If yes, then keep the new user ID, but the authorizations should be reassigned to the 'new' users and also make sure to assign the 'new' users to the projects and tasks in SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation.

entry.title: Re: How to extend validity with SAP ALM user
entry.content: please also refer to 3378674 - SAP Cloud ALM User with status "Expiring in xx Days"

entry.title: Re: Export of CDS View generates two lines for one Product
entry.content:
Hello @KeLaw 

Thank you for your question.

Many CDS views including those for material master deliver texts in all maintained languages. This leads to multiple rows per key. So, the behaviour you are experiencing is expected.

Yes, it can be prevented. This will require you to restrict your CDS views to expose only one language. You can achieve this by:

  • Adding a filter on the language key field in your CDS views. This ensures only the logon language is retrieved.
  • You can also create a custom CDS view on top of it in the app if you are working with a released data source. In that view, filter the text join condition to restrict to one language.
  • Based on your screenshot, there is not option to suppress languages globally. Therefore, if you require English, you need to log on in the respective language or you build a wrapper custom CDS view with the language filter.

Consult Custom CDS Views for more details.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Custom Logic S/4 Hana Public Cloud

entry.title: Re: API Call to an OAuth 2.0 Endpoint in S/4HANA Public C...
entry.content:
Hello @marceloromeiro 

Thank you for your question.

When consuming an external API through communication arrangements using OAuth 2.0, the 401 error you are experiencing points towards either a mismatch in configuration between cloud and the external service or it can relate to how the access token is being retrieved.

I suggest you check if:

  • In your communication system you have the correct token Service URL, Client ID and secret are entered correctly and the authentication method is correctly set.
  • Ensure that your OAuth 2.0 points in the correct communication system and credentials match API expectation.
  • In Postman you may have successfully done that but in cloud, if you didn’t configure this properly in the communications arrangement, the token request may be rejected by the external provider. I suggest you compare token request payload from both systems.
  • Also check if the external API expects a custom header or a particular token format. If yes, then you must adapt accordingly.

The following references provide more details.

Setting Up Outbound HTTP Connections (with OAuth)

Application Log

Communication Management

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Controlling Area in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content: Hi @Janet_Salmon - thanks for the explanation. I understand that S/4HANA Public Cloud enables CO management reporting in company code currency via ACDOCA as well as non-leading fiscal year variants, but have a concern about activity prices. Because they are maintained in the controlling area currency, production order variances — particularly price variances — may be distorted by exchange rate fluctuations, even though the underlying costs (e.g. labour or machine hours) are local. Could SAP clarify: 1. How potential FX distortions in production order variances are mitigated? 2. Is there a plan to support activity price determination in local currency for manufacturing operations?

entry.title: Re: Custom depreciation key Public cloud 2% declining bal...
entry.content:
Hello @Kunal_G 

Thank you for your question.

Your observation is correct. In your scenario it is not possible to create completely custom declining balance methods if they do not already exist in the available method catalog. The expert configuration template in Public Cloud does not permit you to change the declining factor or edit existing methods within the chart.

Alternatively, you can:

  • Request a new method from SAP through the customer influence channels if this is critical to your business but this would be a long-term solution.
  • You may handle special calculations outside SAP by using analytical or reporting tools or you can maintain a parallel local asset ledger.
  • The Private Cloud and On-premise environment permit custom methods and full flexibility. You may consider this if is a persistent business requirement.

Consult Depreciation Keys for more details.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to avoid FX distortions in production order variances when activity price is at CO Area?
entry.content:
Hi, I understand one CO area is supported in S/4HANA Public Cloud and wish to clarify implications for activity price determination and its use in production orders in the context of a global manufacturing business:

  1. As I understand, activity prices (e.g. labour hours, machine hours) are still calculated and maintained in the controlling area currency.

  2. These activity prices are then used to value internal activity allocations on production orders.

  3. This raises a concern that production order variances (especially price variances) could be influenced by currency exchange fluctuations, even when the underlying cost inputs are local (e.g. local wage rates or machine costs).

entry.title: How to speed up depreciation for an asset's rest life
entry.content:
Hi,

I have one question about depreciation. Our company need to move to new Office, I want to speed up an asset depreciation. My question is: I want to keep the depreciation history not change, but for the rest useful life, for instance, It still has 10 months, 1000cny/Month to run depreciation, now I need to let it complete in 5 months, 2000 cny/month to run the net value to zero.

I tried to added an interval date and set the useful life to 5 period, but the weird was, the depreciation be calculated in only 1 month, not 5 months,  the net value became zero directly. what wrong with my set?

entry.title: How to find test id for uploaded test cases
entry.content:
Hello Team,

 

We are unable to see a test case id for uploaded test cases in SAP Cloud ALM. The test cases are planned for manual execution. Could you please let us know how we can enable ids for each test case and where we can see it?

 

Thanks,


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to find test id for uploaded test cases
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

 

Thanks for contacting SAP.

 

According to the developer, all newly created TM objects (Testcases + TestPlans) automatically receive unique IDs when persisting.

1. The Test Case IDs are available when you select a single test case from the list and navigate to the Test Case Editor app in TM-Preparation-UI or the Test Run app in TM-Execution-UI.
Eg: manual/XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX/tab/content

2. Test Plan IDs are assigned as display IDs. For example:
Plan 03 – Test Plan Title
X-X-XX – TestPlans.DISPLAY_ID

If you need additional features related to unique IDs, please describe the requirements and share screenshots.
You can also create a new feature request in Influence, as outlined in KBA KB0746513 (SAP Note 3391676) related to the Influence process.

Please kindly have a try and feel free to let me know when further inquiries.

 

Best Regards,

Sunny

SAP Support

entry.title: BKP - Customer Returns Project Solution for Advanced Intercompany Sales
entry.content:
Context

Since year 2022, advanced intercompany sales (Single Level / Single System), using scope item 5D2, is available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition. It is a better solution compared with the classical intercompany sales solution.

Advanced Intercompany Sales - Single Level / Single System

For more details, read the blog:

Advanced Intercompany Sales & Stock Transfer in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Below is an example of the solution process flow for 5D2 in value chain monitor, starting with sales order 17729.

Nowadays, there is no standard, corresponding customer returns solution for advanced intercompany sales.

In your project, you will need to identify an appropriate customer returns solution for advanced intercompany sales (5D2).

In this blog, several project solutions are proposed for managing returns of advanced intercompany sales, you can select the most suitable one based on your business needs.

 

Solution Option 1: 2F4 Classical intercompany returns  

In general, the classical intercompany returns process is a simplified, out of box solution.

Classic Intercompany Returns - Single Level / Single System

Below is the classical intercompany returns solution process flow with reference to sales order 17729. This is available in returns overview at item level in manage customer returns version 2 App.

Step by step guidelines are available in scope item 2F4 .

 The Solution option 1 includes the following highlights:

  • For selling company and delivering company – there is no need for an explicit customer/supplier relationship.
  • Returned Product is physically shipped back to delivering company’s plant directly.

However, there are some special restriction or limitation to consider with this option

  • Important: Technically, if you have activated scope item 5W2 (Group Valuation), the system will not allow you to activate classic intercompany processes - including this scope item 2F4.  Check more in KBA 3093830 - SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Release Restriction Note for Group Valuation. 
  • As this is the classical solution, the new concept or innovation in 5D2 are not available in 2F4.
    • No returns purchase order, and no supplier credit memo in selling company, and no intercompany returns order in delivering company.
    • No transit plant concept in selling company in such classical intercompany returns.
  • Additionally, the classical intercompany returns, whether used for classical intercompany sales or advance intercompany sales, have specific by-design features and limitations:
    • During goods receipt, returned product is automatically valuated in receiving company and the sales cost is reversed. This is by design.
    • If there is a material inspection split for returns delivery item, intercompany credit memo process is not supported at this time.

 

Solution Option 2: BKP Customer Returns - Using Logistical Follow-Up Activity (LFU) 0007 – Directly ship to supplier

In general, the option 2 is a customized and simplified solution.

In this solution option, basically, for intercompany returns end to end process, we split the returns process for selling companying and delivering company. Each company runs BKP (customer returns) separately. We utilize the predefined logistical follow-up activity (LFU) 0007 “directly ship to supplier” in the selling company.  This solution option has the following highlights:

  • We establish an internal customer (selling company) and internal supplier (delivering company) relationship - Treating delivering company as the supplier for selling company. 
  • Like outbound shipment from delivering plant in sales process, in this return’s scenario, product is returned to delivering plant (delivering company) directly.
  • Enhanced document flow - returns purchase order and supplier credit memo in selling company, and intercompany returns order in delivering company are created.
  • Inventory, sales cost and revenue can be reversed with regular finance accounting in the two companies.

Selling company handles the returns from the end customer as follows:

  1. Create a returns order with reference, using logistical follow-up activity 0007 “direct ship to supplier”. Use the business partner (BP) of the delivery company code as supplier, not the delivery plant. Select the right return-to address from the supplier. Change the plant to the plant of selling company, instead of the copied intercompany plant.
  2. No returns delivery to the selling company – the customer sends the goods to delivery company directly.
  3. A returns purchase order for the delivering company is created following step 1.
  4. Receive a credit memo from the delivering company and perform supplier credit memo verification.
  5. Determine refund for the end customer with credit memo request and credit memo.

Delivering company handles (internal) customer returns from selling company as follows:

  1. Create a returns order to handle (intercompany) customer returns from the selling company.
  2. The returns delivery is created, and post goods receipt once the end customer ships back the product.
  3. Perform product inspection and decide the final logistical follow-up as usual.
  4. Determine the refund for the internal customer – selling company with credit memo request and credit memo.

There are some special restrictions or takeaways to consider for this option

  • Returns order creation in the selling company
    • Intercompany plant can’t be used if it is copied from sales order. Use the plant belonging to the selling company. Transit plant designed in 5D2 might be used.
    • Use the BP of delivery company code as the supplier. The BP of the delivering plant is currently not supported. Ensure you select the right return-to address based on the supplier.
  • Returns Purchase Order (RPO) in the selling company
    • It would be automatically created with LFU 0007. RPO might encounter the account assignment category issue as it is created with reference to the purchase order (PO) from sales process. Today, expert configuration can be considered for RPO creation without reference.
  • Supplier Credit Memo in the selling company
    • Manual creation is required. With B2B/EDI between the selling company and delivering company, automation is possible.
  • Intercompany returns order in the delivering company
    • It can only be created without reference.
    • Use the BP of selling company as the sold-to party.
  • Other processes in delivering company are performed as usual, such as the product by default not being valuated during goods receipt.

 

Solution Option 3: BKP Customer Returns - Using Logistical Follow-Up Activity 0005 – Ship to supplier

In general, option 3 is a customized solution, and you can adopt it if it matches your real returns process.

In this solution option, basically, for the intercompany returns end-to-end process, we split the returns process for the selling companying and delivering company. Each company run BKP (customer returns) separately. We utilize the predefined logistical follow-up activity 0005 “ship to supplier” in the selling company. his solution option has the following highlights:

  • We establish an internal customer (selling company) and internal supplier (delivering company) relationship - Treating delivering company as the supplier for selling company. 
  • in this return’s scenario, the product is returned to the selling company plant first and then returned to the delivering plant (delivering company) as 2nd step.
  • Enhanced document flow – a returns purchase order and supplier credit memo in the selling company, and intercompany returns order in delivering company are created.
  • Inventory, sales cost and revenue can be reversed with regular finance accounting in the two companies.

Selling company handles returns from the end customer as follows

  1. Create a returns order, using logistical follow-up activity (LFU) 0001- receive into plant. Use the plant of the selling company.  
  2. Returns delivery is auto created, and post goods receipt once you receive the returned product from the customer. 
  3. Perform material inspection, using LFU 0005 – ship to supplier – treating delivery company as the supplier (here use the BP number of delivery company code as supplier).
  4. Returns purchase order is created in above step 3. Perform the outbound delivery to ship the returned product to delivery company.
  5. Receive the intercompany credit memo from the delivery company and perform credit memo verification.
  6. Determine the refund for the end customer with credit memo request and credit memo.

Delivering company handles intercompany customer returns from selling company as follows

  1. Create a returns order to handle the intercompany customer returns from the selling company.
  2. Returns delivery is created post goods receipt when you receive the returned product from the selling company.
  3. Perform product inspection and decide the final logistical follow-up activity.
  4. Determine the refund for the internal customer – selling company with credit memo request and credit memo.

There are some special restrictions or takeaway to consider for this option

  • Returns order creation in selling company
    • Intercompany plant can’t be used if it is copied from sales order. Use the plant belonging to the selling company for the physical receiving of the returned product.
  • Material Inspection in selling company
    • Use logistical follow up activity 0005 “ship to supplier” to forward the returned product to the delivery company. Use the BP of the delivery company code as the supplier. BP of the delivering plant is currently not supported.  RPO might encounter the account assignment category issue as it is created with reference to the PO from the sales process. Today, expert configuration can be considered for RPO creation without reference.
  • Supplier Credit Memo in selling company
    • Manual creation is required. With B2B/EDI between the selling company and delivering company, automation is possible.
  • Intercompany returns order in delivering company
    • It can only be created without reference.
    • Use BP of selling company as the sold -to party.
  • Other processes in delivering company are performed as usual, such as product by default not being evaluated during goods receipt.

 

Master Data Set Up for Option 2 and 3

For Solution Option 2 and Option 3, there are below tips to highlight

  • Use the BP of delivery company code as the supplier. Do not use the BP of the delivering plant.
  • For supplier master data
    • Ensure the returns supplier is selected. With selection, you must assign a customer (same partner with customer role) to deal with the outbound shipping for returns purchase order.

 

  • You might maintain the right return–to address for the supplier if option 2 is used.  Check the help document Return-to Address Determination for Supplier Returns
  •  Ensure you have the right info record maintained for the returns purchase order.

 

Summary

3 solution options in project for intercompany returns to deal with advanced intercompany sales are recommended.

You can adopt the suitable one in your project, considering the restrictions and takeaways in each solution.

生成的会计凭证如下：

贷：收入 100  ARS，

贷：增值税 21  ARS（21%的税率），

贷：代收代缴税  1   ARS(1%的税率) 。

entry.title: Re: How to avoid FX distortions in production order varia...
entry.content: Hi @mpavan_kumar, I understand that the architecture of Public Cloud is a single Controlling Area, I'm interested in what strategies companies use to isolated the FX impact for a global manufacturing company. For example, if a US based company has a subsidiary in Australia, internal activities in Australia will be allocated on the basis of USD. The local cost inputs in AUD may be stable, but reporting would show significant price variances due to FX fluctuation. How does S/4HANA Public Cloud mitigate the potential distortion of production order variances caused by foreign exchange effects, given that activity prices are valued in the controlling area currency? Is there a recommended approach (e.g. use of additional currency types in ACDOCA, parallel valuation methods, or reporting layers) to ensure that local production managers can analyse variances in their own local currency without exchange rate noise? Are there roadmap items to enable more direct maintenance or derivation of activity prices in local currency while retaining the global benefits of a single controlling area?

entry.title: The Internal Party Flag in SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
If you’ve ever worked on a sales quote in an integrated setup, you’ve probably faced this situation:

  • You add your Pre-Sales Consultant or Approval Manager as a party in the quote.
  • You replicate the quote to S/4HANA, and suddenly, the backend system is confused. “Who is this role? Where do I map it? Why is it here?”

This is a common pain. Sales reps often work with roles that are important internally but have no relevance in ERP. That’s where the Internal Party Flag comes in.

Why We Needed This

Sales reps don’t just work with customers,  they collaborate with internal specialists, consultants, and managers who help shape a deal that the  backend ERP systems may not care about 

How do we let sales teams add internal-only roles to quotes without cluttering ERP or risking overwrites from backend replication?

The Objective

To give sales reps flexibility and control, SAP Sales Cloud V2 now allows certain party roles to be flagged as internal-only.

  • These roles live purely in Sales Cloud.

  • They don’t flow into S/4HANA or other backend systems.

  • And they’re protected from being overwritten by inbound ERP updates.

It’s a simple checkbox, but it solves a big problem.

Two Common Use Cases

1. Internal-Only Roles
Picture a rep assigning a Pre-Sales Consultant to a quote. This person is critical for internal reviews within the CRM but irrelevant to ERP. By marking the role as internal, it stays inside Sales Cloud, excluded from the integration payload.

2. Prevent External Overwrites
Let’s say S/4HANA tries to update the quote with its own payload. If that payload includes an internal role, Sales Cloud ignores it. The internal data stays intact.

By turning on the Internal Party Flag, they separated the two worlds:

  • ERP got only the clean, customer-facing roles it needed.

  • Sales Cloud kept the internal collaboration intact.

  • The sales team stopped wasting time fixing integration errors.

How It Works

The solution is straightforward: an Internal Flag for party roles in Sales Quotes.

  • Internal roles are not sent to external systems during quote creation and simulation.

  • They also cannot be updated by incoming payloads from ERP.

All you need to do is head to:
User Menu → Settings → All Settings → Sales Quotes → Party Schema,
and check the Internal box for the role you want to keep inside Sales Cloud.

What to Keep in Mind

  • You cannot set the Account party role as internal.

  • The feature is currently in Restricted Release. To activate it, you’ll need to raise an SAP Incident.

 

Wrapping Up

Sometimes, the smallest features bring the biggest relief. The Internal Party Flag gives sales reps the freedom to collaborate with internal roles without worrying about backend clutter.

Customer-facing data stays clean, ERP stays happy, and your sales team gets a smoother quoting experience.

Next time you’re setting up party roles in Sales Cloud, look for that little checkbox; it might just save you a lot of headaches.

entry.title: Discrepancy in TDS Deduction During CN Booking
entry.content:
Hello All,
I hope this message finds you well.
I would like to bring to your attention a discrepancy observed during the booking of a Credit Note (CN) in DHL Express (160086) related to FY 2024-25. The CN was created due to an invoice initially booked with an incorrect GST head.

However, during the CN booking in SAP, TDS was deducted at 2%, whereas, at the time of the original invoice booking, SAP had deducted TDS at 1.35% as per the applicable Lower Deduction Certificate (LDC).

Kindly review this discrepancy and advise on the necessary steps to align the TDS treatment correctly in the system.

Looking forward to your prompt response.

entry.title: SAP FICO Scenario – Vendor Invoice Posting
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

SAP FICO Scenario – Vendor Invoice Posting – FB60 / F-43

Path: Easy Access -> Accounting -> Financial Accounting->Accounts Payable->Document Entry-> FB60 – Invoice/ F-43 - Invoice - General


Scenario Question:
A vendor has supplied raw materials worth ₹1,00,000 plus 18% GST. You need to post this vendor invoice in SAP. How will you handle this transaction in SAP FICO?

Answer (Step-by-Step):
1. Transaction Code:
Use FB60 / F-43 (Vendor Invoice Posting).

2. Entry Details:

Vendor A/c (Credit) – ₹1,18,000 (₹1,00,000 + ₹18,000 GST)

Raw Material Expense/Inventory (Debit) – ₹1,00,000

Input GST A/c (Debit) – ₹18,000

3. Accounting Entry:

Dr Raw Material A/c ₹1,00,000
Dr Input CGST A/c ₹9,000
Dr Input SGST A/c ₹9,000

     Cr Vendor A/c ₹1,18,000

4. Explanation to Interviewer:

Vendor is credited since we owe him money.

Expense/Inventory is debited as we received goods.

GST is debited to claim input tax credit.

Pro Tip to Mention in Interview:
Always highlight how SAP automatically links this entry to the Reconciliation Account for vendors in G/L.

Kartheek

entry.title: Dynamic MTD/QTD/YTD Calculation in SAC story using Restricted Measure
entry.content:
Introduction

Business users often need to analyze performance not just for the current month, but also on a cumulative basis for the year. Typical requirements include:

  • Month-to-Date (MTD)

  • Year-to-Date (YTD)

In SAC, these comparisons can be achieved with restricted measures and calculated measures, ensuring results update dynamically based on the month selected.

Nomenclature

We’ll use the following shorthand throughout:

  • CY → Current Year

  • PY → Previous Year

  • Cur → Current (Month/Year)

  • Prev → Previous (Month/Year)

Example: Month Selected = Nov 2014

Month-to-Date (MTD)

Measure Definition Example (Nov 2014 selected)
CY Cur MTDCurrent Year Current MTDNov 2014
CY Prev MTDCurrent Year Previous MTDOct 2014
PY Cur MTDPrevious Year Current MTDNov 2013
PY Prev MTDPrevious Year Previous MTDOct 2013

Year-to-Date (YTD)

Measure Definition Example (Nov 2014 selected)
CY Cur YTDCurrent Year Current YTDJan–Nov 2014
CY Prev YTDCurrent Year Previous YTDJan–Oct 2014
PY Cur YTDPrevious Year Current YTDJan–Nov 2013
PY Prev YTDPrevious Year Previous YTDJan–Oct 2013

 

Final Output

When implemented in SAC, the tables update automatically based on the month selection.

For Nov 2014 selected:

Metric

CY Cur

CY Prev

PY Cur

PY Prev

MTD

Nov 2014

Oct 2014

Nov 2013

Oct 2013

YTD

Jan–Nov 2014

Jan–Oct 2014

Jan–Nov 2013

Jan–Oct 2013

We will be using the same nomenclature below.

Start by creating restricted measure on the base measure below.

MTD (Month-to-Date)

CY Cur MTD

CY Prev MTD

PY Cur MTD

PY Prev MTD

 

YTD (Year to date)

CY Cur YTD

CY Prev YTD

PY Cur YTD (Calculated Measure)

PY Prev YTD (Calculated Measure)

Final Output

Based on the Month Selection, the tables update with numbers automatically.

Conclusion

By combining restricted measures and calculated measures in SAC, you can design reports that automatically adjust to user-selected months. This eliminates manual effort and provides instant insights for business users.

References

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/everything-you-need-to-know-about-cumulative-sum-in-sap-analytics-cloud/ba-p/13569357

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud V2 Sales Quotation : August Edition
entry.content:
Every month, SAP Sales Cloud keeps evolving with features that make life a little easier for sales reps, managers, and admins. Starting this month, I’ll share a quick roundup of the key innovations for Sales Quotation processes: what they are, why they matter, and how they could impact your day-to-day work.

So let’s dive into the August release highlights.

Products from Past Quotes

Imagine a repeat customer asking for “the same as last time.” Instead of digging through history, you can now pull products directly from past quotes. Search across past quotes using predefined queries: Sales Quotes of Account, All Past Quotes, My Past Quotes, My Past Quotes for Account, Sales Area.

Why it matters: Speed and consistency. No more re-entering items or worrying about missing something from before.

Getting Started

Available by default in the “Add from List” option in the quote product table.

 

Customer Part Numbers & GTIN in Quotes

Every company has its own way of naming products. Customers often don’t care about your internal codes; they want to see their part numbers. Add to that, many industries (retail, pharma, manufacturing) rely on GTINs for standard product identification.

Now, both Customer Part Number and GTIN fields can be used in quotes.

Why it matters: Reduces confusion between internal and customer codes and ensures accuracy in orders

 

Address Change for Parties 

Customers often want changes in delivery, Ship- To or billing addresses.  Sales reps can change the addresses of any account party (e.g. SHIP-TO) to another maintained at the business partner. Works for both account and individual customer parties.

Why it matters:  Reduces costly rework and ensures accuracy in quotes.

Getting Started

Available by default. In card/table views of involved parties, use inline edit to select another address

 

Internal Parties (Restricted Release)

You know how quotes often involve more than just the customer? There are players internal to CRM, such as approvers, pricing specialists, or even sales ops folks. Now, you can mark these roles as internal parties. This keeps things transparent inside your org without cluttering up what gets synced to backend systems like S/4HANA.

Why it matters: cleaner separation of internal vs. external roles, fewer sync headaches, and better accountability.

Getting Started

Go to User Menu → Settings → All Settings → Sales Quotes → Party Schema. Select the Internal checkbox for the role. (Restricted release – raise a SAP Incident to activate.)

You can refer to this detailed blog here - Internal Parties

 

Tables - Sorting and Resizing 

Admins can define which column a sales quote list view is sorted by. Sales users can see which column the list is sorted on.

Column Resize: Users can adjust table column widths in quote lists and product tables.

Getting Started

  • For sorting: Adaptation → Edit section for table → Sort → Select default sort.

  • For resizing: Available by default : just drag column edges to resize.

Other Notable Enhancements

  • Full-Screen View of Activities: Zoom into activities (calls, meetings, tasks) without distractions for better planning.

  • Autoflow: Admins can configure autoflows using array fields of sales quotes.

  • Adaptation: Visual filters in sales quote list views now support flexible adaptation.

  • Search Improvements: Type-ahead search for sales quotes now supports “Related to Account” queries.

  • Org Unit OVS: Sales quotes now support org unit selection within Object Value Selector for extension fields.

Wrapping Up

The August release is a mix of practical usability tweaks and powerful quote enhancements. Together, they remove friction from daily sales work, from avoiding duplicate effort to making sure the right data shows up in the right place.

I’ll be back next time with another round of updates. Till then, which of these features do you see making the biggest impact in your sales process?

Hi, this feature is planed for Q4 2025 in SAP Cloud ALM and will be soon on roadmap explorer.

Title: Public API for Libraries
Scope Description:
Enable external access to SAP Cloud ALM Libraries via standardized public APIs. The feature provides programmatic read and write capabilities for library content (e.g., Applications, Interfaces, Executables, Development Objects) to integrate with external tools, automate updates, and support enterprise-wide reuse.

entry.title: Re: ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development
entry.content:
Hi @Kartheek ,

the note 3578329 describes which technology components belong to which clean core level. But this not mean that all APIs belonging to this component are recommended to use. Each component typically comes with released APIs (Level-A) or classic APIs (Level-B) but also has some internal APIs which are not for use for custom code. Good example is the ALV. The component is rated as Level-B and it comes with a set of classic APIs described in the cloudification repositories. These are the APIs that you should use to work with ALV in a clean core way. The internal APIs can still be used but are not recommended and therefore belong to Clean Core Level-C. There are other components like for example the application Log that also has released APIs that can be used in ABAP Cloud (Level-A). Hope this helps to understand the idea a bit better. 

Regards,

Thomas.

Total credit sales during the period

entry.title: Re: CDS view: Which annotations do I need for BW extracti...
entry.content:
Hi,

Should you ignore the warnings? No.

Your approach conflicts with the validator rule.

  • For C2 objects ADT only allows a very small set of annotations (intended for OData Remote APIs). Analytical / data-extraction annotations are not allowed on C2, so ADT shows:

    • ANALYTICS.DATACATEGORY is not allowed

    • ANALYTICS.DATAEXTRACTION.* is not allowed

    • ABAPCATALOG.VIEWENHANCEMENTCATEGORY is not allowed (DDIC-view annotation; not valid for view entities in general)

For BW/4HANA extraction via ODP/ODQ, your CDS is not a Remote API. You should not set C2. Use Local/Not specified (C1 “Released (local)” is fine), and keep the extraction annotations.

Try below options

  1. Revert API state from C2 to C1 (Released – Local) or leave Not specified.

  2. Keep:
    @analytics: {
    dataCategory: #FACT,
    dataExtraction: { enabled: true, delta.changeDataCapture.automatic: true }
    }

  3. Remove DDIC-only annotations such as @AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory (not valid on view entities).

They indicate the wrong API state and an invalid annotation set for a view entity. After switching away from C2 and removing DDIC-only annotations, the warnings will disappear, and the extractor will be valid for BW/4.
